video.title: Learn Docker - DevOps with Node.js & Express
video.description:
Learn the core fundamentals of Docker by building a Node/Express app with a Mongo & Redis database.

We'll start off by keeping things simple with a single container, and gradually add more complexity to our app by integrating a Mongo container, and then finally adding in a redis database for authentication. 

We'll learn how to do things manually with the cli, then move on to docker compose. We'll focus on the challenges of moving from a development environment to a production environment. 

We'll deploy and Ubuntu VM as our production server, and utilize a container orchestrator like docker swarm to handle rolling updates.

✏️ Course developed by Sanjeev Thiyagarajan. Check out his channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC2sYgV-NV6S5_-pqLGChoNQ

⭐️ Course Contents ⭐️
0:00:14 Intro & demo express app
0:04:18 Custom Images with Dockerfile
0:10:34 Docker image layers & caching
0:20:26 Docker networking opening ports
0:26:36 Dockerignore file
0:31:46 Syncing source code with bind mounts
0:45:30 Anonymous Volumes hack
0:51:58 Read-Only Bind Mounts
0:54:58 Environment variables
0:59:16 loading environment variables from file
1:01:31 Deleting stale volumes
1:04:01 Docker Compose
1:21:36 Development vs Production configs

Part 02: Working with multiple containers
1:44:47 Adding a Mongo Container
2:01:48 Communicating between containers
2:12:00 Express Config file
2:21:45 Container bootup order
2:32:26 Building a CRUD application
2:51:27 Sign up and Login
3:06:57 Authentication with sessions & Redis
3:34:36 Architecture Review
3:40:48 Nginx for Load balancing to multiple node containers
3:54:33 Express CORS

Part 03: Moving to Prod
3:57:44 Installing docker on Ubuntu(Digital Ocean)
4:03:21 Setup Git
4:05:37 Environment Variables on Ubuntu
4:14:12 Deploying app to production server
4:18:57 Pushing changes the hard way
4:25:58 Rebuilding Containers
4:27:32 Dev to Prod workflow review
4:30:50 Improved Dockerhub workflow
4:46:10 Automating with watchtower 
4:56:06 Why we need an orchestrator
5:03:32 Docker Swarm
5:16:13 Pushing changes to Swarm stack

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://freecodecamp.org/news

topLevelComment.author: Alvin Kariuki
topLevelComment.text:
Incase you encounter 
Error
return promise.reject(new errors_1.clientclosederror()); ^ clientclosederror: the client is closed

Reason it occurs: The updated version of redis or node-redis has a particular issue with how we initialize our redis client 

Do the following 
1. Update package.json to "redis": "3.0.0"
2. Stop your containers with the down command
3. Npm install 
4. Restart your containers with --build 

and vuala

topLevelComment.author: tanzim chowdhury
topLevelComment.text: For those of you who are watching this in 2022, for digital ocean, I would highly recommend mongo image 4.2.23-rc0-bionic. When I was trying it with the latest one (6) it kept getting killed. This was most probably due to the fact that the new mongo needs a lot more resources than just 1GB of ram.

topLevelComment.author: Christopher Ogbunuzor
topLevelComment.text: If your nginx container keep exiting after running the "docker-compose -f docker-compose.yml -f docker-compose.dev.yml up -d" command the first time, run it one more time and the nginx container would not exit

replies.author: Sagar Kanojia
replies.text: Thanks, worked, but need a permanent solution

replies.author: Pianistprogrammer
replies.text: I checked the logs of the container  and i get this error message : host not found in the upstream "node-app" in /etc/nginx/conf.d/default.conf:10 I have tried to solve this, but haven't been able to

topLevelComment.author: Christopher Ogbunuzor
topLevelComment.text: To avoid "CLIENT CLOSED ERROR", use redis v3.1.2 instead of version 4+. Use "npm uninstall redis" to remove redis version 4 and install version 3.1.2 using --> npm i redis@3.1.2

topLevelComment.author: Anindya Bhattacharya
topLevelComment.text:
Thank you so much, Sanjeev. Learned a lot.
Just one small issue, .dockerignore does not ignore files in dev, as the dev has a bind mount and it gets copied over after being ignored. If bind-mount points to a different location in the container other than the work-dir then .dockerignore does its job.

topLevelComment.author: Muhammad Patria
topLevelComment.text:
Hello! Thank you for the tutorial. But I got stuck after following the tutorial on 3:21:50 about authenticating using Redis. After I send the login post, the cookies show the same details with the video, but after that, I see the logs, showing the error, and I cannot post any request on postman, because the postman showing error "socket hangup". The details of the logs is:

/app/node_modules/@redis/client/dist/lib/client/index.js:407
        return Promise.reject(new errors_1.ClientClosedError());
                              ^

ClientClosedError: The client is closed
    at Commander._RedisClient_sendCommand (/app/node_modules/@redis/client/dist/lib/client/index.js:407:31)
    at Commander.commandsExecutor (/app/node_modules/@redis/client/dist/lib/client/index.js:170:154)
    at Commander.BaseClass.<computed> [as get] (/app/node_modules/@redis/client/dist/lib/commander.js:8:29)
    at RedisStore.get (/app/node_modules/connect-redis/lib/connect-redis.js:33:19)
    at session (/app/node_modules/express-session/index.js:485:11)    
    at Layer.handle [as handle_request] (/app/node_modules/express/lib/router/layer.js:95:5)
    at trim_prefix (/app/node_modules/express/lib/router/index.js:328:13)
    at /app/node_modules/express/lib/router/index.js:286:9
    at Function.process_params (/app/node_modules/express/lib/router/index.js:346:12)
    at next (/app/node_modules/express/lib/router/index.js:280:10)    
[nodemon] app crashed - waiting for file changes before starting...  

Do you have any idea what happens?

topLevelComment.author: Baran T
topLevelComment.text:
If you have Windows 10 Home, don't bother installing docker. You need Windows 10 Pro version to run it.

Solution 1: Reset your computer and install windows 10, and then activate a pro key. Most of the time Windows doesn't allow upgrading from Home to Pro.

Solution 2: Create a VM and continue your work from there.

topLevelComment.author: Bernd Bausch
topLevelComment.text: @1:38:05 The statement 'if [ $NODE_DEV = "development" ]' requires spaces because '[' is a command (it's an alternative to the 'test' command). The condition between the square brackets consists of three parameters to the '[' command, which need to be separated from each other.

topLevelComment.author: KimJong Un
topLevelComment.text:
@freeCodeCamp.org there is a slight error at 38:57 

I am using MacOS Big Sur and when I am running the command it says 'docker: invalid reference format: repository name must be lowercase.' 

the solution is that we will have to put the $(pwd):/app in double quotation. 

Like this :- docker run -v "$(pwd):/app" -p 3000:3000 -d --name node-app node-app-image 

Then it will ask for permission, click on allow and then it will run.

topLevelComment.text:
Hi fellow coders, I am currently running into an issue on 1:14:00 Seems the image andcontainer gets created but never starts or keeps getting exited with (127)... Google says its a file path issue but the thing is my files looked exactly like Sanjeevs, and I have not varied the directory or changed the name of the files. Has anyone ran into this or know what may be the cause? Thank you in advance! 

For reference 

PS C:\Users\rex_p\Documents\docker-hw\node-docker> docker ps -all      
CONTAINER ID   IMAGE          COMMAND                  CREATED          STATUS                       PORTS     NAMES
1d94806c9ac6   f26f5c017877   "docker-entrypoint.s…"   55 seconds ago   Exited (127) 7 seconds ago             node-docker_node-app-rex69_1

Hi, why do you write the env file in the command but the port param contains the value 4000 again? Then we have to maintain the port at 2 different places? You have in your Dockerfile an ENV entry for the port and in the docker-compose file en entry for the port. This is a little bit confusing which one is the right thing.

Wouldn't it be better to use env-variables in the dockerfile in order to execute the right npm install command?

docker run -v "%cd%":/app -p 3000:3000 -d --name node-app node-app-image

This is a great tutorial!!

replies.author: Aaron Adams
replies.text: @Chien. To an extent... but keep in mind there are differences in inter-service communications and maybe even more event driven in nature.  For example you might want to use Kafka for events between services.  Also it's recommended that each service have it's own db.  So it's similar in tech but much different in style.

replies.author: Chien.
replies.text: Basically, you can think microservices system as docker compose with multiple services.

replies.author: sam hadi
replies.text: A microservice tutorial would be awesome, but for now knowing docker, kubernetes, pub/sub, queues, load balancers, and also dealing with data consistency between services, and also understanding event driven architecture in general would be good to know before that and there is many videos about that. Building production grade microservice that actually scale and aren’t a nightmare to manage is quite complex and requires alot of smart design choices and knowledge to pull off, good luck on your journey friends
